title: AT-3: Role-Based Security Training
description: Specialized security training tailored to specific job roles and responsibilities within ClearTriage
objectives: Understand role-specific security requirements and training
Learn specialized security practices for your job function
Identify when and how role-based training is delivered
Recognize the importance of training before privileged access

content.title: Introduction to Role-Based Security Training
content.content:
One size doesn't always fit all when it comes to training! üéØ

Role-based training means we tailor extra training content based on your specific job duties. Since we're a six-person outfit, you might wear multiple hats, but we can group our responsibilities to cover what each person needs.

Think of it as specialized security training that's actually relevant to your day-to-day work ‚Äì not just generic theory that makes you wonder why you're learning about things you'll never use.

content.title: Foundation: General Awareness for All Roles
content.content:
**Everyone gets the baseline training first!** üìö

Before we dive into specialized content, everyone gets the baseline training (that's the AT-2 stuff ‚Äì security awareness, phishing, basic IT hygiene, etc.). That covers the common ground applicable to every role.

No one is exempt from knowing things like:
‚Ä¢ How to spot a scam or phishing email
‚Ä¢ Why we don't share passwords
‚Ä¢ Basic security hygiene
‚Ä¢ Company-wide security policies

But on top of that foundation, you'll get specialized training based on your specific role...

content.title: Technical/Developer Roles
content.content:
**For our code ninjas and infrastructure wizards** ü•∑ (looking at you, Savvy and Braden!)

If you are a developer, DevOps engineer, or otherwise handle our AWS cloud environment, codebase, or infrastructure, you receive specialized training before you get production access, and annually thereafter.

## What's Covered:
‚Ä¢ **Secure coding practices** ‚Äì avoiding common vulnerabilities like SQL injection, cross-site scripting
‚Ä¢ **Code review with a security mindset** ‚Äì spotting potential issues before they become problems
‚Ä¢ **Secure configuration of AWS services** ‚Äì keeping our cloud environment locked down
‚Ä¢ **Vulnerability management** ‚Äì finding and fixing security bugs
‚Ä¢ **Incident response procedures** ‚Äì what to do when things go sideways
‚Ä¢ **Proper management of access keys and secrets** in AWS

## Training Approach:
We use real-world scenarios (e.g., "What do you do if you find a security bug in the app?") to train our tech folks. Don't worry, we keep it practical ‚Äì no 100-slide death by PowerPoint.

If you're writing code or deploying infrastructure, this training is a must before you touch live systems. Think of it as earning your "keys to the kingdom" ‚Äì or in Savvy's case, the keys to the samurai dojo! üóùÔ∏è

content.title: Operational/Administrative Roles
content.content:
**For our operations and admin heroes** üìã (Shelly, this definitely includes you as our FedRAMP Coordinator!)

If your role is more on the operations, support, or administrative side, you'll get role-based guidance on practical day-to-day security practices.

## Key Training Areas:
‚Ä¢ **Data handling procedures** ‚Äì proper management of business records and files
‚Ä¢ **Privacy considerations** ‚Äì protecting any user communications
‚Ä¢ **Policy compliance** ‚Äì understanding and following our security policies
‚Ä¢ **Social engineering recognition** ‚Äì since support folks can be targets for trickery
‚Ä¢ **Maintaining confidentiality** ‚Äì not sharing sensitive info over insecure channels
‚Ä¢ **Secure use of Google Drive** for documents
‚Ä¢ **Identity verification** ‚Äì how to verify customer identity before discussing account details

## Why This Matters:
We don't currently collect PII/PHI, but support might deal with user inquiries ‚Äì so it's still important to protect any user communications and not divulge internal info. This training ensures even non-engineers know the rules relevant to their work.

content.title: Executive/Leadership Roles
content.content:
**For our fearless leaders** üëë (Well, we basically have Pete (CTO) and Dave (President))

For leadership, the training emphasizes the strategic and oversight aspects of security.

## Leadership Training Focus:
‚Ä¢ **Understanding compliance requirements** ‚Äì FedRAMP, VA requirements, etc.
‚Ä¢ **Risk management** ‚Äì identifying and addressing security risks
‚Ä¢ **Driving security culture** ‚Äì leading by example
‚Ä¢ **Staying current with FedRAMP updates** and compliance changes
‚Ä¢ **Responding to security audits** from ScaleSec
‚Ä¢ **Training others effectively** ‚Äì since Pete is our in-house trainer

## Leading by Example:
Dave might use his psychic abilities to sense security risks before they manifest (kidding!), but he also needs to understand the strategic security landscape. Pete always completes his training first (well, maybe not first if he's running late, but he gets it done), and he'll often attend external security webinars to bring back knowledge.

So leadership's role training is about being able to champion security and privacy at the organizational level.

content.title: Sales & Clinical Roles
content.content:
**For our customer-facing experts** üéØ (Krista, this one's for you!)

Krista, as our Director of Sales and Clinical Education, gets specialized training on handling customer communications securely, especially given our VA customer base.

## Specialized Training Areas:
‚Ä¢ **Secure customer communications** ‚Äì protecting sensitive discussions
‚Ä¢ **Discussing security features** with potential clients without revealing sensitive implementation details
‚Ä¢ **Confidentiality and verification procedures** ‚Äì her nursing background actually helps here!
‚Ä¢ **Professional communication standards** for government clients

## The Advantage:
Her nursing background from her L&D days already gives her a strong foundation in confidentiality and verification procedures ‚Äì we just adapt that knowledge to our tech environment!

content.title: Multiple Hats & Cross-Training
content.content:
**When you wear many hats** üé≠ (which is pretty much everyone at a 6-person company!)

Given our size, it's common for one person to fill several roles. In those cases, you'll receive all relevant training modules.

## How We Handle It:
‚Ä¢ **Integrated content** ‚Äì We're not going to double the time, but we integrate the content
‚Ä¢ **Well-rounded perspective** ‚Äì You get to see how different roles connect
‚Ä¢ **Cross-functional understanding** ‚Äì You might help connect the dots between teams

## Example:
If you're a developer who also does customer support (maybe while skateboarding, Braden?), you might participate in both the technical training and any ops-focused briefing. The beauty is you get a well-rounded perspective ‚Äì and you might even help connect the dots ("Oh, so that's why the support team needs me to build that feature securely").

content.title: Timing & Training Requirements
content.content:
**When training happens** ‚è∞

We ensure that role-based training is completed **before** you're granted any privileged access or new role responsibilities, and then at least yearly after that.

## Before Privileged Access:
‚Ä¢ If you're moving into a DevOps role and will get AWS admin rights, you'll go through a cloud security training module first
‚Ä¢ If we hire a contractor to help with a task, we'll brief them on relevant security procedures before they start
‚Ä¢ Think of it as earning your credentials before getting the keys

## Annual Updates:
‚Ä¢ Like general training, we'll refresh this role-specific training annually
‚Ä¢ Each year, we re-evaluate what specialized knowledge needs to be reinforced or updated
‚Ä¢ Did AWS release a new security feature? We'll mention it
‚Ä¢ Did our procedures change? We'll update the training

## Keeping Current:
Role-based content is reviewed and updated at least annually (more often if the job function or threats change significantly). We also incorporate any role-specific lessons learned from incidents into the next training.

content.title: Tracking & Completion
content.content:
**Making sure everyone gets what they need** üìä

We maintain a simple matrix of who needs what training. With six people, it's not hard ‚Äì but it is important.

## Our Tracking System:
‚Ä¢ **Simple matrix** ‚Äì Who needs what training for their role(s)
‚Ä¢ **Shelly helps Pete ensure** that all developers have done their secure coding module, all support-facing folks did the privacy module, etc.
‚Ä¢ **Speak up policy** ‚Äì If you ever feel you haven't gotten training you need for your job, speak up! We'll get you covered

## Engagement Approach:
To keep things engaging, role-based training might involve more interactive elements:
‚Ä¢ **Developers** might do a short secure code review exercise
‚Ä¢ **Support staff** might do a role-play of handling a tricky phone call
‚Ä¢ **Everyone** is encouraged to share tips from their experience

We want everyone to feel confident that they know how to do their job securely.

content.title: Final Thoughts
content.content:
## Knowledge Sharing is Welcome! ü§ù

By tailoring training to roles, we ensure relevance ‚Äì you get info that helps you in your day-to-day work, not a bunch of abstract theory. And remember, even if something isn't directly in your role, it can be useful knowledge (no harm in a support person understanding a bit about how our code is secured, for instance).

So we foster an environment where knowledge sharing is welcome.

## *Light-hearted note:* üòÑ
If you find yourself receiving all the role-based modules‚Ä¶ you probably are Pete. Kidding aside, being in a small company means wearing multiple hats, which means learning a bit of everything. Look on the bright side: you'll be a well-rounded security ninja in no time ‚Äì maybe even skilled enough to help Braden finally figure out which state he's from!

## The Big Picture üéØ

Remember: the goal of all this ‚Äì policies, training, insider threat awareness, and role-specific knowledge ‚Äì is to build a secure, privacy-conscious culture at ClearTriage. We're working hard toward our FedRAMP authorization, and that comes with responsibilities that each of us shares.

By staying informed and engaged with this training content, you're doing your part to keep our app safe, our VA customer happy, and our compliance record spotless.

Thank you for taking the time to participate in this training. Security and privacy are truly team efforts, and every one of us is a crucial player. Keep the lessons from this training in mind as you go about your work ‚Äì whether you're building houses by hand (Braden), preparing for a new arrival (Savvy), or using psychic debugging powers (Dave).

## Need Help? üÜò

If you have any questions or need further clarification on any topic covered, reach out to **Pete Allen** (pete@cleartriage.com) or **Dave** if Pete's unavailable. They're always happy to help (and will be even happier that you were paying attention).

In the wise words often repeated in security circles: **"Security is everybody's business."** By being here and staying aware, you've just helped make our business that much more secure. Now, go forth and may your passwords be strong, your emails phish-free, and your jokes be as safe as our AWS servers! üòÅüëç
